headline: As the pandemic rages on, Columbia braces for widespread financial fallout
byline: By Abby Melbourne, Drew Letellier, Dia Gill Data reporting and graphics by Jessica Li

body.value: As the COVID-19 pandemic creates disruptions and challenges to normal campus functions, a potential international economic crisis continues to unfold. With some economists projecting the virus pushing half a billion people into poverty, the stock market drop at the beginning of March—the steepest in the Dow Jones Industrial Average’s history—is a sign of more troubles to come. Within the past month, universities have evacuated their students have been evacuated from campus, canceled in-person university summer programs have been cancelled, and promised room and board refunds have been promised, changes that have leftleaving the higher education industry among those sectors reeling during the chaos.

In an email to faculty and administration at the end of March from University Interim Provost Ira Katznelson noted the particular strain on Columbia’s revenue stems from five principal streams: returns on the endowment, fundraising, federal and private research grants and contracts, clinical income, and tuition—each subject to challenges posed by the virus’s spread.

“We now have to come to grips with fiscal pressures. These are unmatched in my experience in higher education, which includes moments of deep stress, including the early 1970s and the crisis of 2008,” Katznelson wrote.

In contrast to Harvard University’s nearly 30 percent% drop in endowment value from 2008 to 2009, Columbia fared the best among its Ivy Lleague peers in terms of endowment crashes and a loss in fundraising during the Great Recession, due to stability in the other three streams that kept it afloat. But as the global economy braces for a difficult few years ahead, Columbia will have to face the prospect of significant simultaneous losses within each of these revenue streams, which may not be curtailed by efforts such as a hiring freeze for both academic and administrative positions and re-thinking metrics of tenure eligibility.
The Endowment

As colleges and universities nationwide brace for a potential recession, a particular source of economic concern are their endowments. At the end of 2019, Moody’s downgraded the outlook for the U.S. higher education sector from “stable” to “negative,”, indicating an expected lag in net tuition revenue. Columbia’s endowment—managed and invested by the Columbia Investment Company and currently valued at almost $11 billion—is a combination of liquid holdings and long term investments. The University only spends the returns on its investments averaged over three fiscal years, a lagging average designed to cushion itstheir assets from quarter to quarter market volatility. In times of crisis, it is at the discretion of University Trustees to alter their endowment spending policy.
And despite the fragility of the markets, University President Lee Bollinger does not see cause to panic yet.

“When there’s a downturn, Columbia tends to suffer less because other places are more dependent on their endowments,” he said. “No single year should be a test of how your strategy is doing. … I feel very confident on the future performance endowment.”

The University’s endowment assets are divided into hedge funds, global equities, real assets, absolute return strategy funds, fixed income, and cash. The asset allocation is often impacted by economic conditions.

Kenneth E. Redd, the senior director of research and policy analysis for the National Association of College and University Business Officers, advises patience and caution to universities during the COVID-19 crisis.

“Right now every indication that I’ve seen thus far is that most financial managers and investment firms are pretty much saying that institutions should sit tight and not make radical changes in their asset allocation strategy,” he said. “Certainly lots of larger endowments will look at these [economic] crises as opportunities to rebalance their portfolios and might actually buy riskier investments while their prices are cheaper and hope for a recovery.”

The 2019 NACUBOacubo-TIAA Study of Endowments found that large endowments valued over $1 billion, such as Columbia’s, have a smaller share of their assets allocated to American stocks than their peers. Consequently, the large share of Ivy League endowment funds invested in hedge funds and private equity serves universities well, Redd notes.

“The counterintuitive part of endowment investing is that those types of investments, [is] their performance tends to not be correlated with the public stock markets so the larger endowments might arguably do a little bit better than the smaller endowments during this crisis,” he said. “Hedge funds are designed to preserve capital, so they actually might go up during a crisis.”

However, Columbia’s endowment return performance has consistently ranked among the lowest in the Ivy League in the last few years, with last year’s returns coming in at a meager 3.8 percent in comparison to Harvard’s 6.5 percent and Yale University’s 5.7 percent, creating an extra expectation for the University to increase fundraising, cut programs and staff, bring in more students, or raise tuition—all options impeded by COVID-19.
Philanthropy and fundraising

Philanthropy is another key aspect of the University’s funding, generating 10ten percent of Columbia’'s total revenue and accounting for a significant portion of the $1.19 billion dollars spent on research expenditures during the 2019 Fiscal Year. And with the recent introduction of capital university projects like the Manhattanville Campus, a six billion dollar endeavor, and the Climate School (aimed at attracting new donors), this philanthropic funding has become especially necessary moving forward.

Professor David Helfand, the former chair of the department of astronomy, is more concerned about the pandemic’s future impact on philanthropy than other sources of funding, in part due to recessions’ negative impact on philanthropy in the past. Following the Great Recession in 2008, even as Americans donated roughly the same proportion of their income, total individual giving fell between six and seven percent. Philanthropy numbers stayed below pre-recession levels for years afterward.

“The large majority of the money comes from a veryVERY small fraction of large gifts,” Helfand said. “The people who give $100 or $1,000 a year … are important to keep connected to the university, but they don’t give a substantial fraction of the total philanthropic giving.”

Given the concentration of the majority of philanthropic money in a very small percentage of donations [verify], the success of many programs and research groups rides on just a few of the donors’ continued support.
“Depending on what the markets do, [these donors] feel roughly 35 percent poorer than they did a month ago,” he continued.
Among the groups most vulnerable to a potential dip in philanthropy are several Columbia Centers, the majority of which are almost entirely funded through grants and philanthropy.

The Center for Climate and Life, for example, a research group which investigates how climate impacts global food security, doesn’t have a funding recourse if and when philanthropy falls through. According to the center’s director, Peter deMenocal, the research group is not where it wants to be financially at this point.

“The prognosis is not good. … We haven’t raised one-twentieth of what [we] hope to raise,” said deMenocal said. “We’re losing people because of the economy. It’s hard to meet the demand with the funding that is available at the moment. [The current funding] is still a drop in the bucket relative to the scale of the problem.”

The Center for Gender & Sexuality Law faces similarly dire straits. While a lot of the work done is voluntary, such as that by the center’s director Katherine Franke, and will continue regardless of funding, other staff working for the center face a different reality.
“If grants run out and are not renewed, we might have to lay off staff,” Franke said.

Even groups like the Weatherhead East Asian Institute that have been especially prudent with their financial savings face difficulties moving forward, difficulties that go beyond the simple cancellation of a few spring activities.
“We have adjuncts that were teaching for us, [and] we may not be able to pick up their courses in the next academic year,” said Lien-Hang Nguyen, the acting director for the institute, said.

Not every center, however, faces an immediate funding problem. The Center for Computer Music for example, thanks to its low operating costs and staff salaries that are funded internally by the University itself, is better equipped than most to withstand the pandemic’s financial burden.

“Because of the service we provide for both the music department and the school of the arts, we can continue [operations] with no external funding,” director Brad Garton said. “I recognize we’re luckier than most.”

For the Center for Resilient Cities and Landscape too, though the pandemic will influence financial decision making, it won’t pose an existential threat, with the center remaining fully funded for at least one more year, according to director Kate Orff.
President Bollinger echoed these more confident sentiments, pointing out that although fundraising is more challenging in times of recession, it by no means disappears.

“I’ve found that in times of financial stress, people often feel a greater sense of philanthropic interest in helping institutions ... like Columbia in particular,” said Bollinger said. “The need for our great universities and the need for a Columbia is in many ways more apparent when things are bad in the world than when things are good.”
Tuition
The highest grossing revenue stream for the University making upgenerating almost a quarter of the ____—over 1.2 billion dollars—comes from tuition from across the 16 schools at Columbia.

As COVID-19 continues to spread across the globe, and growing international travel restrictions triggerand triggers economic uncertainty across the globe, the enrollment of international students at universities like Columbia—which heavily depends on international student tuition as a main driver of revenue, with 31 percent of its student population coming from foreign countries—may see significant declines in the near future.

But the threat of losing tuition income doesn’t just depend on international students, as universities across the country must also grapple with whether or not to open campus in the fall. On Monday, Boston University became the first American institution to announce that it may not have a fall 2020 semester, instead opening in the spring of 2021. Experts still remain divided as to whether social distancing measures will have lifted enough to allow universities to return to on-campus learning. At Columbia, which made the transition to online learning in early March and cancelled all in-person summer programs shortly after, administrators have yet to confirm whether students will return to campus in the fall. New York state is currently home to the highest population of confirmed coronavirus cases in the world, topping 118,000 in the past week.
National grants and funding <b>

The National Institute of Health, a major source of funding, has provided researchers with guidance on how to extend the renewal dates for grants and hashave allowed faculty working from home to continue getting paid. According to Dr. Michael Shelanski, senior vice dean for research, backlogs of data are keeping researchers occupied for at least the next few months.

“They are insisting they work, and that becomes a somewhat odd definition,” Shelanski said. “People are writing papers;, they’re doing literature research;, they’re analyzing data sets. So they’re keeping as busy as they can.”

Shelanski believes active grants will continue to be a reliable source of income for the term they were originally awarded. Beyond this period of expected stability, he says “no one can predict” what will come. The stimulus bill has allocated almost a billion dollars for COVID-19 research, but it’s unclear how the NIH will distribute this money. According to Shelanski, the NIH spends both extramurally, with grants to universities and research institutes, and intramurally on the large research programs within the NIH.

Under President Donald Trump, the NIH’s budget has already taken several hits. In February of this year, Trump submitted his 2021 budget request, proposing a seven percent cut to the organization’s funding, from $41 billion this year to $38.7 billion. Decreased funding has affected the number of grants that the NIH is able to supply, and as the nation enters a recession, research is set to lose even more.

“If the government, as we come out of this crisis, says, ‘Ooh, we have too much national debt,’ and they cut NIH funding, down the road that could be very detrimental,” said Shelanski. “I would expect when we come out of this, it is going to become economically difficult to conduct research.”

Daniel Savin, chair of the Uuniversity Ssenate research officers committee, represents roughly 1200 post-doctoral research scientists, scholars, and fellows;, 400 staff research officers; and 800 professional research officers. Almost all of the positions he represents are tied to grants from external agencies.

“We have to keep in mind that the entire research enterprise of the United States and the world at large is going to be delayed by this pandemic,” Savin said. “I expect that the agencies that are funding the research will understand this and attempt to take that into account when it comes time to write new proposals or when it comes time to submit annual reports asking for the next year’s funding to be released.”
Clinical income
[Related: CUIMC staff moves to the frontlines to fight the pandemic amid the loss of hundreds of millions in revenue]

In a redirection of resources towards fighting the COVID-19 outbreak, many physicians have left their medical practices to work in the ICUs and emergency rooms.  Non-essential medical procedures have been postponed and non-critical medical practice has ceased in the face of redeployments and social distancing guidelines. In the 2019 fiscal year, medical faculty practice plans generated over $1.3 billion in revenue for the University - over a quarter of the year’s income.

Dr. Michael Shelanski, the senior vice dean for research at the Vagelos College of Physicians and Surgeons, estimated that the medical campus is “losing as much as $100 million a month in revenue because of loss of practice.”
Dr. Lawrence Lustig, a leading expert in hearing loss and chair of the department of otolaryngology- head and neck surgery, estimates that within his own service, revenues are down over 90 percent.

“Us and some of the more surgical specialties are more heavily hit,” he said. “Again, it’s not dictating anything we do right now. There’s a number of potential ways we’re going to rectify this after the fact.”

Lustig believes the two keys to facilitating the Columbia University Irving Medical Center’s financial recovery are government subsidies that will offset revenue losses and a backlog of patients waiting for surgeries and postponed procedures.
